questions.text: A lady has recurrent abortions in the first trimester. The true statement regarding this is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All the given statements are true regarding recurrent abortions in the first trimester

Consanguinity (marriage between close relatives) increases the risk of recessive genetic disorders and may contribute to pregnancy loss, including recurrent abortions. It is recognized as a possible but less common factor in recurrent miscarriage. (Option A)

Chromosomal abnormalities, such as aneuploidy, are indeed the most frequent cause of recurrent first-trimester miscarriages. (Option B)

Uterine didelphys (a double uterus) can contribute to recurrent pregnancy loss, but they are associated with second-trimester loss and not 1st-trimester loss. (Option C)

questions.text: Spontaneous abortion in the 1st trimester is caused by all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rh-incompatibility typically causes complications in later pregnancy rather than early spontaneous abortion. It involves immune reactions between the Rh-positive fetus and the Rh-negative mother, usually affecting pregnancies after the first trimester.

List of common causes of first-trimester spontaneous abortion:

  • Chromosomal Abnormalities: The most frequent cause of early pregnancy loss, including conditions like:
    • Trisomy (MC-16)
    • Monosomy X
    • Other aneuploidies
  • Genetic Factors: Genetic abnormalities in either parent can lead to miscarriage.
  • Maternal Age: Increased maternal age is associated with a higher risk of chromosomal abnormalities and miscarriage.
  • Uterine Abnormalities: Structural abnormalities of the uterus, such as:
    • Septate uterus
  • Endocrine Disorders: Conditions such as:
    • Thyroid disorders (hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism)
    • Diabetes mellitus (poorly controlled)
  • Infections: Certain infections can contribute to early pregnancy loss, including:
    • Listeriosis
    • Toxoplasmosis
    • Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
      INFECTIONS DON'T CAUSE RPL
  • Immunological Factors: Autoimmune disorders and conditions like:
    • Antiphospholipid syndrome
    • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Hormonal Imbalances: Luteal phase defect or inadequate progesterone levels.
  • Trauma: Severe physical trauma can sometimes lead to miscarriage.
  • Environmental Factors: Exposure to certain toxins, drugs, or radiation.
  • Unknown Factors: In some cases, the cause of miscarriage remains unidentified despite evaluation.

questions.text: In a case of recurrent spontaneous abortion, the following investigation is unnecessary:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

TORCH infections (which include Toxoplasmosis, Other infections, Rubella, Cytomegalovirus, and Herpes simplex virus) are not commonly associated with recurrent spontaneous abortions. Hence, testing for the same is not required

Evaluation of recurrent early pregnancy:

  • Karyotyping: This is often recommended, especially if there is a suspicion of chromosomal abnormalities either in the parents or in the miscarried fetuses. Chromosomal abnormality is the most common cause of repeated first-trimester loss. (Option ruled out)
    • The most common type is a balanced translocation of the chromosomes, more likely in the mother. In such cases, the genetic information is intact, so there is no problem for the parents.
    • But this can lead to an unbalanced translocation in the conceptus, causing an early miscarriage.
    • Hence, karyotyping of both partners is recommended in recurrent miscarriage. Prenatal diagnosis is usually advised in the next pregnancy.
  • Testing antiphospholipid antibodies: This is relevant, as an antiphospholipid syndrome can be a cause of recurrent miscarriages due to clotting problems affecting the placenta. (Option B ruled out)
  • Thyroid function tests: Thyroid disorders can affect pregnancy outcomes, so testing thyroid function is often relevant in cases of recurrent miscarriages. (Option D ruled out)

Investigative measures useful in the evaluation of recurrent early pregnancy loss:

  • Parental peripheral blood karyotyping with banding technique.
  • Assessment of the intrauterine cavity with USG, then either office hysteroscopy or hysterosalpingography
  • Thyroid function tests, and serum prolactin levels if indicated.
  • APLA screening - Anticardiolipin antibody and lupus anticoagulant testing (aPTT or Russell Viper venom testing).
  • Complete blood counts with platelet count.
  • Thrombophilia testing:
    • Factor V Leiden, prothrombin gene mutation, Protein S activity.
    • Serum homocysteine level.
    • In the presence of a family or personal history of venous thromboembolism, protein C and antithrombin

questions.text: A 24-year-old female reports to the casualty with a history of amenorrhoea for two and a half months and abdominal pain and bleeding per vaginum for one day. On examination, vital parameters and other systems are normal. On speculum examination, bleeding is found to come from Os. On bimanual examination, the uterus is 10 weeks in size, soft, and Os admits one finger. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical scenario given the most probable diagnosis would be Inevitable Abortion

Inevitable Abortion

Inevitable abortion is a type of spontaneous miscarriage where pregnancy loss is unavoidable. It typically occurs before 20 weeks of gestation.

Key Features:

  • Vaginal bleeding and cramping
  • The cervix is dilated
  • Membranes may rupture, and tissue may bulge into the vagina
  • Products of conception have not yet been fully expelled

Diagnosis:

  • Based on the clinical exam showing cervical dilation and active bleeding
  • Ultrasound may show a nonviable or low-lying gestational sac

Management Options:

  • Expectant: Allow natural passage (if stable)
  • Medical: Misoprostol to assist expulsion
  • Surgical: Dilation and curettage (D&C) if bleeding is heavy or incomplete

Complications:

  • Hemorrhage
  • Infection
  • Retained products of conception

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a history of two episodes of deep vein thrombosis and recurrent second-trimester pregnancy losses. Testing for antiphospholipid antibodies is positive. Which of the following statements regarding lupus anticoagulant is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lupus anticoagulant is a prothrombotic condition, not a bleeding disorder so that the incorrect statement would be Severe life-threatening hemorrhage

Lupus anticoagulant

  • Antiphospholipid antibodies are seen in 5-10% of cases of SLE
  • It may be found in asymptomatic patients with or without lupus, or it may be associated with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS)
  • The term 'anticoagulant' is a misnomer as lupus anticoagulant acts as a procoagulant, causing an increased tendency of thrombosis and does not act as an anticoagulant (it does not lead to life-threatening hemorrhages).

Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS)

APS is a prothrombotic autoimmune disorder that affects both venous and arterial circulations. It is an important cause of thrombosis and adverse obstetric outcomes.

Common Sites of Thrombosis in APS:

  • Venous thrombosis: Most often involves the deep veins of the lower limbs
  • Arterial thrombosis: Commonly affects the cerebral circulation (e.g., stroke)

Obstetric Manifestations of APS:

APS can significantly complicate pregnancy. According to diagnostic criteria, at least one of the following must be present:

  • Unexplained fetal death at or beyond 10 weeks of gestation
  • Preterm birth before 34 weeks due to:
    • Severe preeclampsia
    • Eclampsia
    • Placental insufficiency
  • Three or more consecutive unexplained spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks

Testing is recommended in women with:

  • Unexplained venous or arterial thromboembolism
  • History of one fetal loss ≥10 weeks
  • Three or more recurrent embryonic or fetal losses <10 weeks

Antiphospholipid Antibodies to Be Tested:

  • Lupus anticoagulant (LA)
  • Anticardiolipin antibodies (IgG and IgM)
  • Anti-β2 glycoprotein I antibodies (IgG and IgM)

questions.text: Antiprogesterone compound RU-486 is effective for inducing abortion if the duration of pregnancy is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

RU-486, i.e., Mifepristone, is an analog of the progestin "norethindrone", which has a strong affinity for progesterone receptors but acts as an antagonist of progesterone.

  • Mifepristone is most effective for inducing abortion up to 63 days (9 weeks) of gestation.
  • Beyond this period, efficacy decreases, and the risk of incomplete abortion increases.
  • It is approved for use within 70 days, but 63 days is the most commonly cited cutoff for optimal safety and efficacy.

Given alone, the drug was moderately useful in causing abortion of early pregnancy; however, the combination of mifepristone with an analogue of prostaglandin E1, i.e., misoprostol, is very effective.

questions.text: All of the following drugs have been used for medical abortion except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Atosiban is not used for medical abortion. It is an oxytocin receptor antagonist used primarily to delay preterm labor.
  • Mifepristone and Misoprostolare commonly used for medical abortion. Mifepristone is used to block progesterone, which is necessary for maintaining pregnancy, and Misoprostol induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy. (Option A and B ruled out)
  • Methotrexate is also used for medical abortion, especially in combination with Misoprostol, though it's more commonly associated with early pregnancy termination. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: In extra-amniotic 2nd-trimester medico-legal termination of pregnancy, which of the following is used?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the context of a second-trimester medico-legal termination of pregnancy, particularly via extra-amniotic instillation, the substances used include:

  • Ethacridine lactate is one such substance used for extra-amniotic termination in the second trimester. It is an antiseptic that has been used for this purpose in certain regions and protocols.
  • Mifepristone(B) is more commonly used for first-trimester medical abortion rather than second-trimester extra-amniotic procedures.
  • Hypertonic saline(C) was historically used for second-trimester terminations but is less commonly used today due to safety concerns.
  • Glucose(D) is not used for this purpose.

Second Trimester (13-20 Weeks) MTP:

  • ProstaglandinsPGE1(Misoprostol), 15-methyl PGF2a (Carboprost), PGE2(Dinoprostone), and their analogues (used intravaginally, intramuscularly, or intra-amniotic ally)
  • Dilation and evacuation(13-15 weeks)
  • Extra-amniotic-Ethacridine lactate, Prostaglandins (PGE2,PGF2a)
  • Oxytocin infusionhigh dose is used along with either of the above two methods
  • Intrauterine instillation of hyperosmotic solutions, Intra-amniotic hypertonic urea (40%), saline (20%)-seldom used nowadays

Hysterotomy (abdominal) - less commonly done

Methods of Medical Termination of Pregnancy First Trimester (Up to 12 Weeks)

MEDICAL

  • Mifepristone
  • Mifepristone and Misoprostol (PGE1)
  • Methotrexate and Misoprostol
  • Tamoxifen and Misoprostol

Surgical

  • Menstrual regulation
  • Vacuum Aspiration (MVA/EVA)
  • Suction evacuation and/or curettage
  • Dilatation and evacuation:
  • Rapid method
  • Slow method

Explanation of Other Options:

Mifepristone (Option B): It is more commonly used for first-trimester medical abortion rather than second-trimester extra-amniotic procedures.

Hypertonic saline (Option C): This was historically used for second-trimester terminations but is less commonly used today due to safety concerns.

Glucose (Option D): not used for this purpose.

questions.text: Suction evacuation can be done up to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Suction evacuation is a commonly used method for first-trimester abortion, typically performed up to 12 weeks of gestation.
  • Other related techniques include:
    • Menstrual regulation
    • Manual vacuum aspiration (MVA)
  • Both methods are based on the principle of vacuum aspiration, which allows for the effective removal of products of conception from the uterine cavity.
  • Importantly, MVA and menstrual regulation do not require electricity, as they utilize a manual hand-held syringe to generate negative pressure.

High probability of nonviable pregnancy - but still repeat scan after 7 days to confirm
Can be ectopic pregnancy - give methotrexate

questions.text: A P2 + 1 female comes with amenorrhea of 5 weeks. Her UPT is +ve. On USG, Gestational and yolk sacs are seen in the uterus. No fetal pole is visible. No fetal cardiac activity is seen. CRL is 8 mm and MSD = 28 mm. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given case is of missed abortion, and the next best step is to repeat the scan after 7 days to confirm

Missed abortion criteria (Non-viable pregnancy):

In early pregnancy, certain ultrasound findings help determine viability:

  • A mean gestational sac diameter (MSD) ≥ 25 mm with no visible embryo suggests a blighted ovum (anembryonic pregnancy).
  • A crown-rump length (CRL) ≥ 7 mm with no cardiac activity indicates an embryonic demise.
  • So in the question, MSD is 28 mm and CRL 8 mm, and still no cardiac activity or fetal pole is visible. It has to be a nonviable pregnancy.
  • In this case, we should perform immediate MTP or repeat the scan after 7 days. This approach allows for reassessment to confirm whether the pregnancy is viable or not.
  • Early pregnancy scans can sometimes show uncertain results, and a follow-up scan helps in providing a more accurate diagnosis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Advise MTP as it is a non-viable pregnancy (Option A):

  • While the measurements (CRL ≥ 7 mm, MSD ≥ 25 mm) strongly suggest a nonviable pregnancy, current guidelines recommend confirming nonviability with a repeat ultrasound after 7 days.
  • Immediate medical termination without confirmation risks misdiagnosis due to late ovulation or inaccurate dating.
  • So, MTP should not be performed immediately.

Can be an ectopic pregnancy (Option C):

  • Ectopic pregnancy is ruled out by the presence of an intrauterine gestational sac and yolk sac.
  • Methotrexate is used to treat confirmed ectopic pregnancies, and using it here would be inappropriate and dangerous.
  • This option reflects a misinterpretation of the ultrasound.

High probability of viable pregnancy - repeat scan after 7 days(Option D):

  • There is no high probability of viability in this case.
  • The absence of fetal cardiac activity with CRL ≥ 7 mm is not a reassuring finding.
  • While a repeat scan is still the right next step, this option misrepresents the clinical interpretation by falsely implying the pregnancy is likely viable.

questions.text: The number of the cannula corresponds to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shown is of Karmans' cannula, and the number of cannulas corresponds to the diameter of the cannula in millimeters. A plastic cannula is preferred because it is less traumatic, transparent, and disposable.

Karman cannula

A long tubular structure made of plastic or metal.

  • Types: Rigid or flexible
  • Sizes: 4-12 mm
  • Parts
  • Distal end: Double whistle at the terminal end.
  • Proximal end: Fixes into the syringe.
  • Superior overhanging edge acts as a curette.

Clinical Uses:

  • Suction evacuation in:
    • First-trimester abortion
    • Missed or incomplete abortion
    • Molar pregnancy
  • Endometrial sampling/biopsy
  • Evacuation in secondary postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) due to retained products

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman undergoes suction evacuation for an incomplete abortion. During the procedure, the instrument shown is used to remove retained products of conception. Identify this instrument:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical scenario and the image shown, the probable instrument would be Haywood Smith's ovum forceps

Haywood Smith ovum forceps

Designed by Haywood Smiths.

Parts & Features:

  • Blades: Spoon-shaped, fenestrated, blunt-ended
  • Fenestrations: Longitudinal, to hold a good amount of tissue
  • Lock: Absent - no catch lock or serrations
  • Grip: Holds tissue firmly without crushing

Differentiation from Sponge Holding Forceps:



Clinical Uses:

  1. Evacuation of Products of Conception
    • In abortion procedures
    • In vesicular mole (molar pregnancy)
  2. Management of Secondary Postpartum Hemorrhage (PPH)
    • To evacuate retained placental fragments
